docs.lead_paragraph: IF you've seen more than one suspense movie, you know that it's just when a character is standing on the deck of his new boat, calm and confident and looking out into the sunset, that everything generally goes wrong. So, maybe, in retrospect, that should have been the tip-off. In August 2000, Gene Murdock was, in fact, standing on the deck of his new houseboat, docked on the shore of Clarks Hill Lake on the Georgia-South Carolina border. He was on the cellphone to his broker and friend, Joseph Harris of the Merrill Lynch office in Augusta, Ga., a few miles away.

headline.main: When Stock Tips Go Bad, Is the Broker to Blame?

docs.snippet: Can poor stock-picking advice from brokers be used by investors as evidence to get back some of the money they lost?

docs.lead_paragraph: The Dark Side of the Deal To most investors, mergers are the stock market's equivalent of catnip. Takeover bids typically provide a nice boost to investors' portfolios and confirm their stock-picking smarts. And to hear the executives orchestrating them tell it, they always produce greater profits at the combined company down the road. Business publications and newspapers, including The Times, celebrate the deals with breathless tales of how they came together, complete with photographs of smiling executives shaking hands in front of a crowd. This year, with the stock market moving sideways, buyouts and the gains they generate are prized all the more. There have been a lot of them, too. This year, according to Thomson Financial, the first quarter's combinations were valued at $308.2 billion, up 17 percent from the value of deals announced in the same period in 2004. If this activity continues, 2005 will be the fourth-largest year in deal size.
docs.snippet: Not much, unless you're one of the bankers or executives whose compensation goes up with every deal you do.

multimedia.credit: Sweetheart deals for C.E.O.'s and executives.
multimedia.caption: The Truth Behind Mergers & Acquisitions

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: Sweetheart deals for C.E.O.'s and executives.

docs.lead_paragraph: FRENCH and Dutch voters have ushered in a fresh period of political and economic uncertainty for the European Union by rejecting its proposed constitution, but many professional investors with global stock portfolios say the region still offers better prospects than the United States over the near to medium term. Their reasoning is that the American economy has enough uncertainty of its own. Francis X. Claro, senior portfolio manager at Evergreen Investments in Boston, said that in the United States ''there's a 6.5 percent current account deficit, an environment of rising rates, some inflation, oil is very high and you have a fiscal deficit.''

headline.main: Should Your Portfolio Vote 'Yes' on European Stocks?

docs.snippet: Many professional investors with global stock portfolios say Europe offers better prospects than the United States over the near to medium term.

docs.lead_paragraph: Among the many things a mother influences in a daughter's life is her attitude toward health and doctors. Sheila Solomon Klass and her daughter, Dr. Perri Klass, were recently asked to trade thoughts on the topic. PERRI -- Several years ago, I had a bad cold that wouldn't go away. My voice sounded terrible and my mother was worried. It is my policy never to tell my mother very much about my health. I can't stand solicitous inquiries, and I find that the loving concern of others often gets in the way of my own precious denial. But in this case, my mother could hear that I sounded lousy. And she wanted me to see a doctor.

headline.main: Who Needs the Doctor? And Other Inherited Traits

docs.snippet: Among the many things a mother influences in a daughter's life is her attitude toward health and doctors.

byline.original: By PERRI KLASS, M.D., and SHEILA SOLOMON KLASS

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: It is chilling to think that the unworkable proposals coming out of a large new coalition of interest groups are passing for serious solutions to the problem of the increasing number of people who have no health insurance (''Health Leaders Seek Consensus Over Uninsured,'' front page, May 29). The statement by the president of the American Academy of Family Physicians that different solutions are needed for different groups of the uninsured takes us to the heart of the problem. Incremental, patchwork solutions simply do not work. They are too expensive, confusing, wasteful and, worst of all, temporary. As fast as we can cover one person or group, another one loses coverage.

headline.main: Patchwork Solutions Won't Help the Uninsured

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Eyeing the Future With Caution, an Old Union Fights Once More'' (May 29) was a story of former warriors fighting to get what was promised them. The International Ladies Garment Workers Union's officers and staff were idealists who worked for low wages, believing in the cause of fighting for exploited workers.

docs.lead_paragraph: Gian S. Sangha wanted to work so badly he cut his hair and removed his turban when interviewing, even though it compromised his Sikh beliefs. He sent hundreds of résumés. He prayed fervently and finally bought a Buddha statue for good luck. But Mr. Sangha, 55, an environmental scientist from India, could not seem to get a job in Canada, his adopted country, despite a doctorate from Germany, two published books and university teaching experience in the United States.

headline.main: Some Skilled Foreigners Find Jobs Scarce in Canada

docs.snippet: Years ago, Canada encouraged professionals around the developing world to settle there, but recent studies indicate that employment prospects for immigrants are deteriorating.

multimedia.credit: Canada for decades has encouraged immigration, but now employment prospects for foreigners appear to be deteriorating.
multimedia.caption: Trouble Finding Work in Canada

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: Canada for decades has encouraged immigration, but now employment prospects for foreigners appear to be deteriorating.

docs.lead_paragraph: Job creation slowed to a crawl in May, the Labor Department estimated on Friday, but the unemployment rate edged down to its lowest point since September 2001. The nation added 78,000 jobs in May, about half the pace of the previous three months and the smallest monthly increase in nearly two years.

headline.main: Hiring Brakes Sharply After Big April Gains

docs.snippet: Job creation slowed to a crawl in May, but the unemployment rate edged down to its lowest point since September 2001.

docs.lead_paragraph: The rich world is searching for ways to help Africa. At the meeting of industrialized countries in July, there will be pronouncements about how to funnel money to Africans beset by poverty, disease and wars. There will be talk about modalities, measurements and criteria, and how to bypass corrupt officials and get help to where it's needed. What the rich world should be talking about is how to give money to Charity Kaluki Ngilu.

headline.main: In Kenya, a Woman Called Charity Takes On the Establishment

docs.snippet: The rich world should be talking about how to give money to Charity Kaluki Ngilu, the Kenyan minister of health.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In David Brooks's view, we should give up hope of attaining the quality of life found in Western Europe and embrace the dog-eat-dog world of hard-nosed capitalism.

headline.main: Europe, the Good Life and Us
